author: Jordan Raanan | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Giants wide receiver Victor Cruz gets injection in injured calf, per reports
text:
Comments 
Giants wide receiver Victor Cruz had a platelet-rich plasma (PRP) injection Thursday in his injured left calf, according to multiple reports. PRP is supposed to promote healing in the affected area. PRP is used to promote healing & decrease inflammation. Is painful initially and takes 2-6 wks to work. #Cruz @Giants — David J. Chao, MD (@ProFootballDoc) October 2, 2015 Cruz aggravated a calf strain Wednesday in his first practice back. He lasted three plays after originally hurting the calf last month, admittedly a result of overcompensation following a serious knee injury he suffered last year. 
The explosive wide receiver was on track to return for the start of the season prior to the calf problem. He has yet to appear in a game, preseason or regular season. 
There is currently no timetable for his return, but it does not appear it's on the horizon. #VictorCruz recent PRP injection in calf puts Week 5 & more in jeopardy. Typically takes 2-6 weeks to work. @RVacchianoNYDN @DanGrazianoESPN — David J. Chao, MD (@ProFootballDoc) October 2, 2015 PRP is a commonly used procedure on athletes. Blood is generally drawn and spun down, then reinjected into the injured area. 
According to the Hospital for Special Surgery (HSS): "Platelet activation plays a key role in the process of wound and soft tissue healing. The use of platelet rich plasma (PRP), a portion of the patient's own blood having a platelet concentration above baseline, to promote healing of injured tendons, ligaments, muscles, and joints, can be applied to various musculoskeletal problems." Results with PRP are generally mixed. It believed to have limited side effects "as the patient is utilizing their own blood, which they should have no reaction to," according to HSS.
